document.title: Archdiocese of Milwaukee Curriculum Guide, Grade 1

B7DA9DA3A8D74F668220D93F7CB86FAC.description: Determine the unknown whole number in an addition or subtraction equation with three whole numbers

2D42BA39CCF545168035A585B4E0D7F4.description: Recognize part-part-whole relationships of addition and subtraction equations

1D77DD96AEA14A91AE913B7FB7AE7F2F.description: Determine the unknown whole number in an addition or subtraction equation relating three whole numbers. For example, determine the unknown number that makes the equation true in each of the equations 8 + ? = 11, 5 = _ - 3, 6 + 6 = _.

A426192372FB4365884FA96DE4FD044D.description: Determine if an equation is true or false

DAE358B393E145F99E94256CB668C576.description: Compare the values on each side of an equal sign

9581D06170854920A827F7F84365F0BE.description: Explain the meaning of an equal sign (the quantity on each side of the equality symbol is the same)

197D18714AF947DD822C2D381E233D69.description: Understand the meaning of the equal sign, and determine if equations involving addition and subtraction are true or false. For example, which of the following equations are true and which are false? 6 = 6, 7 = 8 - 1, 5 + 2 = 2 + 5, 4 + 1 = 5 + 2.

CA57843E1F8D4274BAD2492CF80C0E75.description: Apply strategies to add and subtract within 20

173EAD7B6CB94CC492FCBE911F083031.description: Add and subtract within 20, demonstrating fluency for addition and subtraction within 10. Use strategies such as counting on; making ten (e.g., 8 + 6 = 8 + 2 + 4 = 10 + 4 = 14); decomposing a number leading to a ten (e.g., 13 - 4 = 13 - 3 - 1 = 10 - 1 = 9); using the relationship between addition and subtraction (e.g., knowing that 8 + 4 = 12, one knows 12 - 8 = 4); and creating equivalent but easier or known sums (e.g., adding 6 + 7 by creating the known equivalent 6 + 6 + 1 = 12 + 1 = 13).

2C44639FDA0049EB9BA7EFF21E04416D.description: Explain how counting on and counting back relate to addition and subtraction

5534F5053C974F2D95611FFA3B36E76A.description: Know how to count on and count backÂ

751AEBB021874216A14AD977A9FCCF4D.description: Relate counting to addition and subtraction (e.g., by counting on 2 to add 2).

9A2EA3016C3E44D29AAACA3BFCF67B82.description: Explain the relationship of addition and subtraction

D2B716D64E6D49409DAB9EC26E17CCD8.description: Solve subtraction problems to find the missing addendÂ

530A065F5C6048CAB705FD8A4B80D14D.description: Identify the unknown in a subtraction problem

FC796A562B2B4B00B160C3CFD3D0678D.description: Understand subtraction as an unknown-addend problem. For example, subtract 10 - 8 by finding the number that makes 10 when added to 8.

D511328F20E34279A11FC58611F0DE29.description: Apply properties of operation as strategies to solve addition and subtraction problems

349C4F6B95664EAAA70B27B88DA80018.description: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add and subtract. Examples: If 8 + 3 = 11 is known, then 3 + 8 = 11 is also known. (Commutative property of addition.) To add 2 + 6 + 4, the second two numbers can be added to make a ten, so 2 + 6 + 4 = 2 + 10 = 12. (Associative property of addition.)

530D2BB3BF4D4E82A906C1BF89F6AAA2.description: Solve word problems that call for addition of 3 whole numbers whose sum is less than or equal to 20

31D6F8D9E3954643890C429EB56B4522.description: Know how to add three whole numbers whose sum is less than or equal to 20

5633E9BF60F1462D96C5997AC4DABCA6.description: Solve word problems that call for addition of three whole numbers whose sum is less than or equal to 20, e.g., by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.

5B4312E4C5AD4B84BEFCCACD8281B2D4.description: Solve word problems within 20 using addition and subtraction

4137284195534A5F9ECCA337A4841A0F.description:
Determine appropriate representations for solving word problems involving different situations using addition
and subtraction within 20

75E8822E16644550ADB4710E19BE1672.description:
Interpret situations to solve word problems with unknowns in all positions within 20 using addition and
subtraction

FF7C7D04F7F748C6B4769F98D85CE333.description: Use a symbol for an unknown number in an addition or subtraction problem within 20

608639739B6849B2848E8939993F6EC6.description: Use addition and subtraction within 20 to solve word problems involving situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g., by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.

2869EDF52E4D4BB9B7571AEE0A826E9B.description: Relate the chosen strategy to a written method (equation) and explain the reasoning used

A0E373DFDE5E4072A0561D3B820FA69A.description:
Choose appropriate strategy (concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of
operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction) for solving subtraction problems with
multiples of 10

FD504945444C4259B94A01F350677A85.description:
Subtract multiples of 10 in the range of 10-90 from multiples of 10 in the range of 10-90 (positive or zero
differences)

EE3862C56FF24E3AA49AF783EDAC7474.description: Subtract multiples of 10 in the range 10-90 from multiples of 10 in the range 10-90 (positive or zero differences), using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.

C4D4FE0CE6CB4513A195B2EE3A8E76CC.description: Apply knowledge of place value to mentally add or subtract 10 to/from a given two-digit number

54AF6A8D23014F3EBDDBF77468F3FBA7.description: Explain how to mentally find 10 more or 10 less than a given two-digit number

E3A46DC71B354CF1BEB5DA754B1E563C.description: Identify the value of each digit in a number within 100

511AB076996743418D2C2D24667307B6.description: Given a two-digit number, mentally find 10 more or 10 less than the number, without having to count; explain the reasoning used.

8A92FB36DE2644DCA518AA848B9464D0.description: Use composition and decomposition of tens when necessary to add within 100Â

183A6D64D55C4C51B093EEEE1DD82851.description:
Relate the chosen strategy (using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of
operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtractions) to a written method (equation) and
explain the reasoning usedÂ

40949E2784BA49259C967D864C1A67F7.description: Choose an appropriate strategy for solving an addition problem within 100

4C1AC1CB0C1C476695407B8AA1C3CCED.description: Decompose any number within one hundred into ten(s) and one(s)

F43391BAD4534ACC9B18DB214940610D.description: Identify the value of each digit of a number within 100

614B4E2A8D90404B9414D322FE5CC27B.description: Add within 100, including adding a two-digit number and a one-digit number, and adding a two-digit number and a multiple of 10, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used. Understand that in adding two-digit numbers, one adds tens and tens, ones and ones; and sometimes it is necessary to compose a ten.

AD4105EA64D0439E87D6C12B6E41CDF4.description: Use greater than, =, and less than symbols to record the results of comparisons

515DD3F3C9414730AE6EFD556457F868.description: Compare two two-digit numbers based on meanings of the tens and ones digit

EC09E57D5E544B25A6E395CA137660C6.description: Know what each symbol represents greater than, less than, and =

1EAE031334584F94BA7813582DDBC79D.description: Identify the value of each digit represented in a two-digit number

8052BDCEC0F542E5B2CF9DCB94BBB920.description: Compare two two-digit numbers based on meanings of the tens and ones digits, recording the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, and <.

A20272EB32EB4F779E3ADD618399139B.description: Represent the numbers 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, and 90 as composed of the correct number of tensÂ

9DD7DB6DECA54ED6871167680E5E2816.description: Represent numbers 11-19 as composed of a ten and correct number of ones

5A4BFFDB61D740B9B1A07480DF62D800.description: Define a bundle of 10 ones as âtenâ

56C75EE194984183B86C53B8A5CEBDE0.description: Explain what each digit of a two-digit number representsÂ

E53488C7A3FD4047B322AD1C70B4BDB4.description: Understand that the two digits of a two-digit number represent amounts of tens and ones.Â

78C2C438E0754463A30B81DA8ADE1AD6.description: Read and write numerals up to 120

9080EED3B66E4273AD437E87F6FAB878.description: Count to 120, starting at any number less than 120Â

5C390FC0C2844AE0B5E9E1D431C2E1EC.description: Represent a number of objects up to 120 with a written numeral

0D1DB68ECA8B42EC9373EA2FD0E95C09.description: Recall numbers and numerals up to 120

E7ACEC2374B44A7FA912C885F08B2B81.description: Count to 120, starting at any number less than 120. In this range, read and write numerals and represent a number of objects with a written numeral.Â

1870257F1E4D4124A513E9DB5D002BB6.description: NUMBER AND OPERATIONS IN BASE TEN

0A3894EC0A9542B880EC3F0463B07F88.description: Interpret data representation by asking and answering questions about the dataÂ

126DA9F4B0F646CD8DE78E1471900B38.description: Represent data with up to three categories

A44F88D24B7745EC8710B7612F799851.description: Organize data with up to three categories

E8B3600439A64F019BDD33A185A7B4A9.description: Recognize different methods to represent data

5A3FC9ECA10642C596F8A3630C388197.description: Recognize different methods to organize data

A853D10391AA49499907C10766B51EC7.description: Organize, represent, and interpret data with up to three categories; ask and answer questions about the total number of data points, how many in each category, and how many more or less are in one category than in another.

98793616370442438A7BD19D103C8273.description: Tell and write the time to the hour and half-hour correctly using analog and digital clocksÂ

8DF81522DC374597B7A3E1124625D651.description: Determine where the minute hand must be when the time is to the half-hour (thirty)

FF825EF024704AD6B9D240B9BABB3DB7.description: Determine where the minute hand must be when the time is to the hour (oâclock)

E362DF0901414DF29C207EA9F151DBC7.description: Know hour hand and minute hand and distinguish between the two

36CD08ED6F944D8798459D3A65BC7B7C.description: Recognize that analog and digital clocks are objects that measure time

E8565CC11769446EBE406A0BE102FA02.description: Tell and write time in hours and half-hours using analog and digital clocks.

60A8076890844AB7A88041EA008DDC08.description:
Compose the measurement of an object using non-standard units (e.g., paper clips, unifix cubes, etc.) by laying
the units of measurement end to end with no gaps or overlaps

C185B658879644BB9C865E1AD55F6C79.description:
Determine the length of a measured object to be the number of smaller iterated or repeated objects that equal
its length

610264D2D4D342BAAF8C094B815568D0.description: Compare a smaller unit of measurement to a larger object

F09998C2BEAE45C0943AA8512353D1F9.description: Know that length can be measured with various units

811E0376C7794AF9BE2D5C0106DCF13E.description: Know to use the same size non-standard objects as repeating units

5469247CDECB497EAF276CA548977C45.description: Express the length of an object as a whole number of length units, by laying multiple copies of a shorter object (the length unit) end to end; understand that the length measurement of an object is the number of same-size length units that span it with no gaps or overlaps. Limit to contexts where the object being measured is spanned by a whole number of length units with no gaps or overlaps.

B6DBAF96C8744D0CB3BBBBAF64CDB506.description:
Compare the lengths of two objects indirectly by using a third object (e.g. if the length of object A is greater than
the length of object B, and the length of object B is greater than the length of object C, then the length of object
A is greater than the length of object C)Â

378B5A004EDF424698553A15761FDC2E.description: Directly compare the length of three objects

4C908C41E96A4863A8FEF7F9F55B70EC.description: Identify the measurement known as the length of an object

FF096DC788254CC18C14E55B84FEEC3B.description: Order three objects by length; compare the lengths of two objects indirectly by using a third object.

D1E25DB57CDD41F6B2BB3B6FB202EB60.description: Analyze that dividing a circle or rectangle into more equal pieces creates smaller shapes

B0E2FF7A04C644BB9217E5435E50084E.description: Describe the whole as two of two or four of four equal shapes

CADE66C95DBC471CAD218CCAC5951A97.description: Describe equal shapes using vocabulary: halves, fourths and quarters, half of, fourth of, and quarter of

00E97132A1EA47A3ACED560A09F22A7E.description: Partition circles and squares into two and four equal shapes

DD84C5950EC640E7A8813C11515FC8B1.description: Partition circles and rectangles into two and four equal shares, describe the shares using the words halves, fourths, and quarters, and use the phrases half of, fourth of, and quarter of. Describe the whole as two of, or four of the shares. Understand for these examples that decomposing into more equal shares creates smaller shares.

99F1B997F37341A0B119C462DA35A6B7.description: Compose new shapes from a composite shapeÂ

EA9B7E6FF7DB4A2ABB49ABA2B6470301.description: Determine how the original and created composite shapes are alike and different

5B6B84F9DB0D4B47AFD53EC7C4E499AD.description: Describe properties of original, decomposed and composite shapes

47BE0D39AB674011831BE6FB3CF72AF3.description: Know that shapes can be decomposed to create composite shapesÂ

CEE8C997092A43B9B70B85C6FD5B6F5E.description: Compose two-dimensional shapes (rectangles, squares, trapezoids, triangles, half-circles, and quarter-circles) or three-dimensional shapes (cubes, right rectangular prisms, right circular cones, and right circular cylinders) to create a composite shape, and compose new shapes from the composite shape.

DD9B2F3BA4CA4D0FB784BDF47F985EE9.description: Build shapes to show defining attributes

A1F920B2267A4B79A827D519E73BABD5.description: Draw shapes to show defining attributes

A531A25396D247B685827BBE4B3ABA9F.description: Compare and contrast defining and non-defining attributes of shapes

B9B388F9267D4739920ECDFA16E4A6E0.description: Identify defining and non-defining attributes of shapesÂ

D0AE5E698A88468C9A272FD0874D086F.description: Distinguish between defining attributes (e.g., triangles are closed and three-sided) versus non-defining attributes (e.g., color, orientation, overall size); build and draw shapes to possess defining attributes.
